Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Helium Diffusion in Lower Mantle Minerals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Helium is one of the most important geochemical tracers of Earth's internal composition and evolution. It consists of two isotopes: 3He, which has a primordial origin, and 4He, which is the product of uranium and thorium decay. The ratio of these two isotopes in samples derived from Earth's mantle is variable, as are the ratios for many other elements. A long-standing question is how the observed heterogeneity in isotopic composition relates to the heterogeneity that is observed by other means, including seismic imaging. To answer this question, it is necessary to know on what length scales isotope heterogeneity can persist in Earth's mantle over geological time, against diffusive and convective mixing. Because helium is a highly mobile element in geological materials, it can provide a lower limit on the length scale of heterogeneous regions that are sampled by geochemical methods. However, while the mobility of helium has been determined experimentally in shallow mantle materials at low pressures, no information is yet available on the mobility of helium in the deepest 80% of Earth's mantle. The proposed work will provide the first data on helium mobility in these deep mantle materials.
The proposed research combines both experimental measurements and first-principles calculations. Experiments will be carried out at CWRU and Harvard to determine the mechanism and rate of He diffusion in periclase, as well as its solubility, over a wide range of temperature and pressure. The diffusivity of He will be determined by incremental outgassing step-heating experiments on He-saturated crystals using the noble gas mass spectrometer at Harvard. Helium diffusivity and solubility at high pressures will be determined through time series experiments in sealed noble-gas charged capsules followed by bulk He analysis of the recovered crystals. Theoretical first-principles calculations will be carried out at the University of Wisconsin to determine He diffusivity and its mechanism in both periclase and MgSiO3-perovskite. The calculations will provide a critical cross-check on the experimental data and extend the study to deep lower mantle conditions that are experimentally inaccessible. The proposed research will provide a fundamental constraint on the minimum length scale of geochemical heterogeneity that can be maintained in Earth's deep mantle. It may also provide indirect insight into the helium mobility in nuclear reactor materials, where helium embrittlement is a persistent problem, and in proposed nuclear waste disposal materials, which include perovskite-structured oxides.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How the heterogeneous nature of the mantle relates to the isotopic signatures in mantle-derived lavas is of significant interest to geologists as it relates to the style and tempo of mantle convection, the main process that extracts heat from the Earth’s interior and controls the exchange of material between the surface and the interior. In particular, the isotopes of helium in mantle-derived lavas have played a key part in the debate regarding the origin of mantle heterogeneity, the structure of the mantle and the preservation of  domains in the mantle that have escaped melting since the formation of the Earth. However, interpreting the helium isotopic measurements in mantle-derived lavas is not straightforward as helium diffusivities are largely unknown in lower mantle phases. The overall goal of this project was to determine the minimum length scale on which He isotopic heterogeneity can be preserved in the lower mantle, by determining He diffusion rates in the lower mantle through determination of He diffusivity in the lower mantle mineral periclase. Furthermore, the project aimed to understand the mechanism of helium diffusion in periclase.

 

Rates of helium diffusion were measured in the mineral periclase. To understand whether diffusion of He is controlled by the migration of cation vacancy or by migration of interstitial sites, some periclase crystals were doped with gallium. The gallium-doping increases the cation vacancy by approximately a factor of 30. To generate a uniform distribution of helium in the crystal lattice of periclase and gallium-doped periclase, an important criterion for determining diffusion coefficients, the crystals were bombarded with a proton beam. Diffusion coefficients were determined by heating the proton-bombarded samples with a laser in a vacuum chamber. The diffusion experiments indicate that rates of helium diffusion are quite similar in the pure periclase and gallium-doped periclase, particularly at temperatures greater than 1000 Kelvin. Therefore, in the mantle, helium diffusion rates would not be primarily controlled by migration of cation vacancy but rather by migration of interstitial sites. Rates of helium diffusion at modest pressures of 2 gigapascals appear to be similar to those determined by heating samples in a vacuum chamber. Based on the experimentally determined rates of He diffusion, helium would migrate on order 5-10 km in the lower mantle over the age of the Earth. Therefore, variations in helium isotopic compositions that are observed in mantle materials source from the lower mantle must be associated with heterogeneities that are larger than a few kilometers in scale.

 

The project involved mentoring and training laboratory assistant Francisco Apen in diffusion theory, mass spectrometry and noble gas geochemistry. Apen was a former undergraduate student at the University of California Davis and a first generation Hispanic student. Based on his research experience in the noble gas laboratory, Apen decided to go to graduate school. He received the highly competitive, NSF Graduate Research Fellowship and joined the Earth Science department at University of California Santa Barbara in 2017. The project also involved the training of graduate student Michael Huh in mass spectrometry and high-precision measurements of noble gas isotopes.
